concept.title: Common use cases

conbody.p: Belows are some common use cases of the desired capabilities for Firefox in Katalon Studio:

li.p: Start Firefox with devtools in private mode. To do so, click Add on the command toolbar, then input the following values:

row.entry: Click More (...). In the pop-up Dictionary Property Builder dialog, click Add, then input values from Table 2.

li.p: Alternatively, you can copy and paste the following script in the settings files.

image.alt: Open Firefox with Devtools in private mode

li.p: Start Firefox at a default page. To do so, click Add on the command toolbar, then input the following values:

row.entry: Click More (...). In the pop-up Dictionary Property Builder dialog, click Add, then input values from Table 2.
Click More (...). In the pop-up Dictionary Property Builder dialog, click Add, then input values from Table 3.

li.p: Alternatively, you can copy and paste the following script in the settings files.

image.alt: Start Firefox with default startup page

li.p: Download files to specified folders. Here, we want to download .html files to the C:\Downloads folder. To do so, click Add in the command toolbar, input the following values:

row.entry: Click More (...). In the pop-up Dictionary Property Builder dialog, click Add, then input values from Table 2.
Click More (...). In the pop-up Dictionary Property Builder dialog, click Add, then input values from Table 3.

Setting this preference as 2 tells Firefox to use the directory specified in browser.download.dir as the download folder instead. You can learn more about this preference in the MozillaZine document here: About:config entries.
Setting this preference as False turns off the showing of download progress.
This preference is to set path for the downloading folder, for example, C:\Downloads.

This preference tells Firefox to automatically download the files of the selected MIME types. The list of MIME types is comma-separated. To find the MIME types of the files you want to download, you can refer to the Mozilla developer document here: Check MIME types.

li.p: Alternatively, you can copy and paste the following script in the settings files.

image.alt: Download HTML file automatically to a folder
